questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of the heat stability of vaccines:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VVM

Highyeild:

A vaccine vial monitor (VVM) is a thermochromic label put on vials containing vaccines which gives a visual indication of whether the vaccine has been kept at a temperature which preserves its potency. The labels were designed in response to the problem of delivering vaccines to developing countries where the cold chain is difficult to preserve, and where formerly vaccines were being rendered inactive and administered ineffectively due to their having been denatured by exposure to ambient temperature. If temperature is maintained properly inner square always remains white. If temperature is not maintained, inner square colour doesn’t remain white, it becomes darker. It has 4 grades. We can use grade 1 & 2 vaccines - i.e. inner square is lighter than outer square. When square colour matches circle colour or is darker, do not use the vaccine. It is a marker of cold chain maintenance. (Indirect marker of Potency).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: The Quantitative method which is best to study previous research studies is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meta-analysis

Highyeild:

Qualitative Data collection method includes: interviews, focused group discussion, Ethnography, Literature, reviews. It is more analyzed through categorising, interpreting and they are expressed in words. Evidence based Medicine (EBM) Top of EBM : Meta Analysis Gold STD for EBM: Meta Analysis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are false. Option A. The basic steps in conducting a RCT include the following: Drawing up a protocol. Selecting reference and experimental populations. Randomization. Manipulative or intervention. Follow up. Assessment of outcome. Option B. Cohort study is a type of analytical study which is usually undertaken to obtain additional evidence to refute or support the existence of an association between suspected cause and disease. Option D. A systematic review is a scholarly synthesis of the evidence on a clearly presented topic using critical methods to identify, define and assess research on the topic. A systematic review extracts and interprets data from published studies on the topic, then analyzes, describes, and summarizes interpretations into a refined conclusion.

questions.text: The discrete probability distribution that expresses the probability distribution that expresses the probability of a given number of events in a particular time frame:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Poisson's distribution

Highyeild:

In statistics, a Poisson distribution is a probability distribution that can be used to show how many times an event is likely to occur within a specified period of time. The Poisson distribution is a discrete function, meaning that the variable can only take specific values in a (potentially infinite) list. The Poisson distribution is used to describe the distribution of rare events in a large population. For example, at any particular time, there is a certain probability that a particular cell within a large population of cells will acquire a mutation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

The Poisson distribution has the following characteristics: It is a discrete distribution. Each occurrence is independent of the other occurrences. It describes discrete occurrences over an interval. The occurrences in each interval can range from zero to infinity.

questions.text: The data which best explains the difference between the highest and the lowest values is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Range It is the difference between the highest and lowest values in a given data.

Highyeild:

Range = Expression of minimum to maximum value. Range = Maximum Value–Minimum Value. For example, the dataset 4,6,10, 15, 18 has a maximum of 18, a minimum of 4 and a range of 18-4 = 14.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false. Option A. Coefficient of variation (CV) is the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean. The higher the coefficient of variation, the greater the level of dispersion around the mean. It is generally expressed as a percentage. Option C. Variance is the expectation of the squared deviation of a random variable from its mean. In other words, it measures how far a set of numbers is spread out from their average value. Variance computation is used to build standard deviation and other statistical functions. To measure spread, variance calculates the mean of all values in the sample. For each input value in the set, the difference of the value from the mean is computed, and this difference is squared. Option D. The interquartile range is a measure of where the “middle fifty” is in a data set. Where a range is a measure of where the beginning and end are in a set, an interquartile range is a measure of where the bulk of the values lie. That’s why it’s preferred over many other measures of spreadwhen reporting things like school performance or test scores.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at a PHC. Which of the following regimens would you advise for mass prophylaxis for anemia?
questions.correct_answer: B. FeSO4 + Vit. C+ Folate +Vit. B12
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FeSO4 + Vit. C+ Folate +Vit. B12

Highyeild:

Most common anemia in India: Iron deficiency anemia. Other nutritional causes of anemia include deficiency of iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12 for mass administration of iron , iron is combined with vitamin B12 as well as folic acid along with vitamin C. Vitamin C is given to facilitate the iron absorption from the gut.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

Table:

In case of SAM children, IFA supplementation should be continued as per SAM management protocol. Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of Folic Acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the foetus. questions.text: Once clinically manifested, which of the following disease has the highest mortality?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rabies

Highyeild:

CFR represents killing power of a disease. Rabies CFR =100 % Case fatality rate of different disease: Rabies: 100% H1N1 : 1-4% H7N9 : 33% Nipah : 50% Ebola : 40% Covid 19: 1.2-2.5%

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are false.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leptospirosis It is spread through urine of infected animals.

Highyeild:

Leptospirosisis spread through urine of infected animals, which can get into water or soil and can survive for weeks to months. The most common method of transmission is through direct contact with infected urine or other bodily fluids such as saliva, or contaminated water, soil, or food. This bacteria can enter the body through skin or mucous membranes (eyes, nose, mouth) especially if skin is broken with cut or scratch. Outbreaks are most commonly associated with contaminated water such as flood waters. Person to person transmission of this bacteria is rare. Both wild and domestic animals can be carriers of this bacteria, this includes but is not limited to: cattle, pigs, horses, dogs, rodents, and wild animals. Animals may show no signs or symptoms of the disease. Clinical presentation of leptospirosis is variable depending on the stage of the disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false. Options B, C and D are not spread by urine of infected animals. S. Typhi is spread through feco-oral route.

Extraedge:

Time between a person’s exposure to the source and showing these signs and symptoms can be 2 days to 4 weeks. Early state signs and symptoms include high fever, headache, chills, muscle aches, vomiting, jaundice, red eyes, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and rash. The second stage presents with more severe symptoms such as kidney or liver failure, meningitis, hemorrhage, hepatomegaly, pulmonary hemorrhage, and ARDS. This phase is also known as Weil’s disease. Case fatality for leptospirosis is 1-5%.

questions.text: In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer? Before examining the patient After examining the patient After touching the patient’s surroundings Hands are visibly soiled Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2 & 3 only

Highyeild:

If the hands are not visibly soiled, rub them with alcohol based sanitizer for a duration of 20-30 seconds. If hands are visibly soiled, then rubbing only not sufficient, you should wash your hands with soap and water for a duration of 40-60 seconds.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

Rubbing with hand sanitization done in the following circumstances: Before touching a patient. Before clean/asceptic procedure. After body fluid exposure risk. After touching a patient\ After touching a patient surroundings.
